definition: Coordinated monitoring where every signatory contributes telemetry, probes, and observers to a shared view.

positive_examples: Telemetry feeds from all signatories arrive on the same cadence.
Monitoring dashboards attribute data to each tribe clearly.
Observers flag anomalies and see responses logged.
Probe health is reviewed holistically, not per tribe only.
Fallback coverage is assigned when a tribe has downtime.
Mutual verification scripts are shared and versioned.
Frontline operators can page the collective command center.
Shared glossary defines gauges and thresholds.
CAT overlays show how each tribe contributes sensors.
Monitoring data includes context for local incidents.
Secure enclaves let tribes inspect raw logs when authorized.
Collective metrics remain accessible to treaty-aligned auditors.
negative_examples: Some tribes deliver telemetry weekly, others yearly.
Probe health is tracked only locally.
Downtime leaves blind spots with no backup.
Operators must escalate through political channels.
Monitoring budgets fall entirely on smaller tribes.
Telemetry gaps accumulate with no follow-up.
CAT overlays show large blind regions.
Context for incidents is missing, so misinterpretations spread.
Raw logs cannot be inspected even under treaty.
Auditors see only local snapshots, not collective metrics.
training_hints.disambiguation: Coordinated monitoring where every signatory contributes telemetry, probes, and observers to a shared view.
